title: Hebrews Chapter 12 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hebrews chapter 12 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hebrews Chapter 12 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hebrews Chapter 12.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12:2, who is the author and finisher of our faith?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:2 states that Jesus is the author and finisher of our faith.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 12:1 encourage us to lay aside as we run the race set before us?
questions.correctAnswer: Every weight and sin
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:1 instructs to lay aside every weight and the sin which so easily besets us.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 12:4 says that believers have already resisted unto blood, striving against sin.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:4 states that ye have not yet resisted unto blood, striving against sin.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12:6, why does the Lord chasten and scourge every son he receives?
questions.correctAnswer: Because He loves them
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:6 explains that the Lord chastens and scourges those He loves.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Hebrews 12:14: 'Follow peace with all men, and ________, without which no man shall see the Lord.'
questions.correctAnswer: holiness
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:14 instructs to follow peace and holiness, for without holiness no one will see the Lord.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 12:15 warn to look diligently lest any man fail of?
questions.correctAnswer: The grace of God
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:15 warns to look diligently lest any man fail of the grace of God.

questions.question: Who is mentioned in Hebrews 12:16 as having sold his birthright for a morsel of meat?
questions.correctAnswer: Esau
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:16 refers to Esau who sold his birthright for one morsel of meat.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 12:17 says Esau found a place of repentance when he sought it with tears.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:17 states Esau found no place of repentance, though he sought it carefully with tears.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12:22, to what place have believers come?
options: Mount Sion and the city of the living God
questions.correctAnswer: Mount Sion and the city of the living God
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:22 says believers have come to Mount Sion and the city of the living God.

questions.question: What is Jesus described as in Hebrews 12:24?
options: The mediator of the new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: The mediator of the new covenant
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:24 describes Jesus as the mediator of the new covenant.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 12:28 encourages believers to serve God acceptably with reverence and godly fear.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:28 instructs believers to serve God acceptably with reverence and godly fear.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 12:29 say about God?
questions.correctAnswer: God is a consuming fire
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:29 declares that our God is a consuming fire.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12:3, why should we consider Jesus who endured such contradiction of sinners?
options: Lest we be wearied and faint in our minds
questions.correctAnswer: Lest we be wearied and faint in our minds
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:3 tells us to consider Jesus to prevent weariness and fainting in our minds.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Hebrews 12:12: 'Wherefore lift up the hands which ________, and the feeble knees;'
questions.correctAnswer: hang down
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:12 instructs to lift up the hands which hang down and the feeble knees.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12:7, how does God deal with us if we endure chastening?
questions.correctAnswer: As with sons
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:7 says God deals with us as with sons if we endure chastening.

medium.title: Hebrews Chapter 12 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hebrews Chapter 12 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling discouraged while enduring trials. Based on Hebrews 12, what biblical truth should you share about perseverance?
options: We must lay aside every weight and run the race with patience
We should avoid all hardships to keep our faith strong
Endurance is not necessary when faith is strong
Trials indicate God’s rejection of us
questions.correctAnswer: We must lay aside every weight and run the race with patience
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:1 encourages believers to lay aside every weight and sin and run the race with patience, emphasizing perseverance through trials. Hebrews 12:3 and 12:11 also remind us to consider Jesus' endurance and that chastening yields righteousness.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 12 describe Jesus' attitude toward suffering, and what can we learn for handling shame and difficulties?
options: He endured the cross, despising the shame, for the joy set before Him
He avoided suffering by relying on angels
He accepted suffering reluctantly and with fear
He refused to endure shame to protect His reputation
questions.correctAnswer: He endured the cross, despising the shame, for the joy set before Him
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:2 teaches that Jesus endured the cross, ignoring the shame for the joy ahead, teaching believers to focus on eternal joy rather than present difficulties. This model encourages faith and trust in God during trials.

questions.question: A believer feels exhausted by opposition from others. What encouragement does Hebrews 12 offer regarding enduring opposition?
options: Consider Jesus who endured opposition from sinners against Himself
Give up when opposition becomes too hard
Avoid people who oppose you at all costs
Opposition means God has abandoned you
questions.correctAnswer: Consider Jesus who endured opposition from sinners against Himself
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:3 instructs believers to consider Jesus' endurance of opposition, which provides strength not to grow weary or faint in heart. This encourages patience and faith amidst trials.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 12 teach about God's discipline and its purpose in the life of a believer?
options: God disciplines those He loves to produce holiness
Discipline is a sign of God's punishment for failure
Discipline is random and serves no purpose
Only some believers receive God's discipline
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines those He loves to produce holiness
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:5-11 explains that God's discipline is an expression of His love, intended for our profit so that we may share in His holiness. Though it may be painful, it yields the peaceful fruit of righteousness.

questions.question: If a believer is tempted to give up under correction, what scriptural encouragement from Hebrews 12 helps them understand their identity in God?
options: Enduring discipline shows we are God’s children, not illegitimate
Discipline means we are not truly God’s children
God’s discipline is optional for believers
Discipline is a sign of God’s anger only
questions.correctAnswer: Enduring discipline shows we are God’s children, not illegitimate
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:7-8 teaches that enduring God's discipline is proof we are His legitimate children, whereas lack of discipline indicates being illegitimate. This encourages submission and perseverance.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 12 contrast earthly parental discipline with God’s discipline?
options: Earthly parents discipline for a few days, God disciplines for our eternal benefit
God’s discipline is harsher and without mercy
Earthly discipline is always better than God’s
God disciplines out of anger, not love
questions.correctAnswer: Earthly parents discipline for a few days, God disciplines for our eternal benefit
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:9-10 explains that earthly fathers discipline according to their pleasure for a short time, but God disciplines for our profit so we may share in His holiness, highlighting God’s loving and eternal purpose.

questions.question: What practical advice does Hebrews 12 give to believers whose faith is weakening or becoming weary?
options: Lift up the hands that hang down and strengthen feeble knees
Avoid fellowship to focus on personal prayer
Ignore your weaknesses and push harder alone
questions.correctAnswer: Lift up the hands that hang down and strengthen feeble knees
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:12 encourages believers to strengthen themselves by lifting up their hands and strengthening weak knees, symbolizing renewed effort and perseverance in faith.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12, what is essential to see the Lord, and how should believers pursue it?
options: Peace with all men and holiness
questions.correctAnswer: Peace with all men and holiness
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:14 teaches that believers should pursue peace with everyone and holiness, as without holiness no one will see the Lord. This calls for active peacemaking and personal sanctification.

questions.question: A believer notices bitterness growing in their heart. What warning does Hebrews 12 give about this attitude?
options: Bitterness can defile many and cause failure of grace
Bitterness is a sign of strong faith
Bitterness is harmless if kept private
Bitterness should be nurtured to gain strength
questions.correctAnswer: Bitterness can defile many and cause failure of grace
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:15 warns that a root of bitterness can cause many to be defiled and cause some to fail to receive God's grace, highlighting the importance of guarding the heart.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 12 use the example of Esau to teach about the consequences of unwise choices?
options: Esau sold his birthright for a single meal and lost his blessing
Esau was rewarded for his patience and faith
Esau became a great leader despite his mistakes
Esau’s story is not relevant to believers
questions.correctAnswer: Esau sold his birthright for a single meal and lost his blessing
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:16-17 cites Esau as a warning that selling one’s birthright for a momentary pleasure leads to loss of blessing and no place for repentance, teaching wise stewardship of spiritual inheritance.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 12 teaches that believers have come to a tangible mountain with terrifying fire and thunder.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:18-21 contrasts the terrifying physical mountain of Sinai with the spiritual Mount Zion where believers now come, indicating a shift from fear to grace and access to God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hebrews 12, refusing to listen to God who speaks from heaven will result in no consequences for believers.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:25 warns that refusing Him who speaks from heaven will bring consequences far worse than those who refused God on earth, showing the seriousness of obedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hebrews 12 tells us that our God is a ________.
questions.correctAnswer: consuming fire
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:29 declares that God is a consuming fire, emphasizing His holiness and the reverence we should have in serving Him.

questions.question: How should believers respond to receiving a kingdom which cannot be moved, according to Hebrews 12?
options: Serve God acceptably with reverence and godly fear
Ignore God’s kingdom and focus on earthly wealth
Demand signs and wonders before serving God
Serve God without respect or fear
questions.correctAnswer: Serve God acceptably with reverence and godly fear
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:28 encourages believers who receive an unshakable kingdom to serve God acceptably with reverence and godly fear, reflecting humility and gratitude.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 12 teach about the mediation of Jesus in the new covenant?
options: Jesus is the mediator of the new covenant, whose blood speaks better than Abel’s
Jesus mediates only for a select few
The old covenant is superior to the new covenant
Jesus is not involved in mediation between God and man
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus is the mediator of the new covenant, whose blood speaks better than Abel’s
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:24 describes Jesus as the mediator of the new covenant whose blood speaks better things than Abel’s, emphasizing the power of Christ’s sacrifice and intercession.

hard.title: Hebrews Chapter 12 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hebrews Chapter 12.

questions.question: In Hebrews 12:2, Jesus is described as the 'author and finisher of our faith.' What Old Testament typology does this role most closely parallel?
options: Moses as the mediator of the Law
Elijah as the prophet of God
questions.correctAnswer: Moses as the mediator of the Law
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:2 depicts Jesus as the author and finisher of faith, paralleling Moses’ mediatorial role in delivering the Law, but Jesus surpasses Moses by completing salvation.

questions.question: Hebrews 12:1 uses the imagery of a 'race' that believers must run patiently. This metaphor is also used by which other New Testament writer?
questions.correctAnswer: Paul in 1 Corinthians
questions.explanation: The metaphor of running a race is used by Paul in 1 Corinthians 9:24-25 to describe the Christian life, emphasizing discipline and perseverance, linking to Hebrews 12:1.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12:6-7, what is the theological significance of divine chastening in the life of believers?
options: It signifies God's rejection of the believer
It is a sign of God's love and sonship
It is a punishment for unrepented sin
It shows that the believer is abandoned
questions.correctAnswer: It is a sign of God's love and sonship
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:6-7 teaches that God chastens those He loves and treats as sons, indicating discipline within a familial relationship rather than rejection.

questions.question: Hebrews 12:16 warns against becoming like Esau, who sold his birthright. What Old Testament event does this allude to, and what is the consequence mentioned?
options: Esau selling his birthright; he was rejected and found no place of repentance
Jacob deceiving Esau; Jacob received the blessing
Joseph sold by brothers; became ruler in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Esau selling his birthright; he was rejected and found no place of repentance
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:16-17 alludes to Esau’s sale of his birthright (Genesis 25), resulting in his rejection and inability to repent, illustrating the gravity of despising God's promises.

questions.question: The 'mountain that might be touched' described in Hebrews 12:18-21 is an allusion to which Old Testament event?
options: Mount Sinai where Moses received the Law
Mount Carmel where Elijah confronted prophets
Mount Moriah where Abraham offered Isaac
questions.correctAnswer: Mount Sinai where Moses received the Law
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:18-21 describes the terrifying experience at Mount Sinai during the giving of the Law, emphasizing the contrast with the heavenly Mount Zion.

questions.question: Hebrews 12:22-24 contrasts Mount Sinai with the 'mount Sion' and the 'heavenly Jerusalem.' What is the significance of this contrast in light of the author’s intent?
options: To show the superiority of the New Covenant over the Old
To emphasize the physical location of heaven
To teach the importance of angel worship
questions.correctAnswer: To show the superiority of the New Covenant over the Old
questions.explanation: The author contrasts the terrifying Old Covenant at Sinai with the joyful access to the heavenly Mount Zion, highlighting the New Covenant’s superior grace and access to God (Hebrews 12:22-24).

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12:25-27, what is the significance of the 'voice from heaven' and the 'shaking' mentioned by the author?
options: It signifies the final judgment and purification of creation
It is a call to return to the Mosaic Law
It warns of a coming famine
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies the final judgment and purification of creation
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:25-27 speaks of God's voice shaking earth and heaven, symbolizing the removal of all that is shaken so that only unshakable divine realities remain, pointing to eschatological judgment.

questions.question: In Hebrews 12:11, what is the 'peaceable fruit of righteousness' that results from chastening, and how does it relate to the broader biblical theme of sanctification?
options: A state of perfect sinlessness achieved instantly
Moral growth and holiness cultivated through discipline
Removal of all suffering from life
questions.correctAnswer: Moral growth and holiness cultivated through discipline
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:11 teaches that discipline, though painful, produces righteous character and peace, resonating with biblical themes of sanctification as a process of growth through trials.

questions.question: Hebrews 12:24 mentions Jesus as the 'mediator of the new covenant' and the 'blood of sprinkling.' What Old Testament covenantal practice does this allude to?
options: The sprinkling of blood on the altar and people during Mosaic covenant ratification
The anointing of kings with oil
The daily burnt offering in the tabernacle
The anointing of priests with water
questions.correctAnswer: The sprinkling of blood on the altar and people during Mosaic covenant ratification
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:24 references the covenantal blood sprinkling in Exodus 24, but Jesus' blood is superior, inaugurating a new and better covenant.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the Greek word translated as 'chasteneth' in Hebrews 12:6, and how does this enrich the understanding of divine discipline?
options: Paideuo, meaning to educate or train
questions.correctAnswer: Paideuo, meaning to educate or train
questions.explanation: The Greek word 'paideuo' in Hebrews 12:6 means to discipline or train like a child, emphasizing God’s loving educational intent in chastening.

questions.question: Hebrews 12:29 states, 'For our God is a consuming fire.' This phrase recalls which Old Testament theophany and its theological significance?
options: God appearing in the burning bush to Moses, symbolizing holiness and judgment
The pillar of cloud guiding Israel, symbolizing protection
The manna from heaven, symbolizing provision
The floodwaters in Noah’s time, symbolizing cleansing
questions.correctAnswer: God appearing in the burning bush to Moses, symbolizing holiness and judgment
questions.explanation: The 'consuming fire' recalls God's holy presence as in Exodus 3, symbolizing both holiness and purifying judgment, reinforcing reverence and fear (Hebrews 12:29).

questions.question: Hebrews 12:9 compares earthly fathers with the 'Father of spirits.' What is the significance of this comparison regarding the nature of divine discipline?
options: Earthly correction is temporary; divine discipline aims at eternal life and holiness
Earthly fathers are always harsher than God
Divine discipline is optional and less important
Earthly fathers have no authority over souls
questions.correctAnswer: Earthly correction is temporary; divine discipline aims at eternal life and holiness
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:9 contrasts temporary human discipline with God’s discipline for our spiritual life and holiness, emphasizing the greater authority and purpose of divine correction.

questions.question: Hebrews 12:15 warns believers to watch for any 'root of bitterness.' How does this concept connect with Old Testament wisdom literature and New Testament teachings on community purity?
options: Bitterness corrupts community and must be removed for holiness
Bitterness is encouraged as a sign of zeal
Bitterness is unrelated to spiritual matters
Bitterness is a sign of divine favor
questions.correctAnswer: Bitterness corrupts community and must be removed for holiness
questions.explanation: The 'root of bitterness' reflects Old Testament wisdom warnings about sin's corrupting effects (Proverbs) and New Testament calls to maintain purity and peace in the community (Hebrews 12:15).

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 12:4 states that believers have already resisted unto blood in their struggle against sin.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:4 explicitly states that believers have not yet resisted unto blood, indicating that their struggle against sin has not been to the point of death.

questions.question: Hebrews 12:12-13 uses the imagery of 'hands which hang down' and 'feeble knees.' What literary device is employed here, and what is its purpose?
options: Metaphor to encourage spiritual strength and recovery
Simile to compare believers to animals
Personification to give human traits to knees
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor to encourage spiritual strength and recovery
questions.explanation: The passage uses metaphorical language to depict spiritual weakness and exhort believers to renew strength and make straight paths, encouraging perseverance (Hebrews 12:12-13).

theological.title: Hebrews Chapter 12 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hebrews Chapter 12 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12:1, what are believers encouraged to lay aside in order to run the race set before them?
options: Every weight and the sin which doth so easily beset us
questions.correctAnswer: Every weight and the sin which doth so easily beset us
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:1 exhorts believers to lay aside every weight and the sin which so easily entangles them to run with patience the race set before them. This is consistent with Paul’s teaching in 1 Corinthians 9:24-27 about running the race to win, and with Jesus’ call in Matthew 16:24 to deny oneself and take up the cross. Isaiah 40:31 speaks of renewed strength for those who wait on the Lord, supporting endurance in the race.

questions.question: Who is described as the 'author and finisher of our faith' in Hebrews 12:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:2 clearly identifies Jesus as the author and finisher of our faith, emphasizing His role in both initiating and completing salvation. This aligns with John 1:1-3 where Jesus is the Word who creates and sustains, and Philippians 1:6 which speaks of God completing the good work He began in believers. Revelation 1:8 describes Christ as the Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end.

questions.question: What motivation did Jesus have to endure the cross according to Hebrews 12:2?
options: The joy that was set before him
To establish a kingdom on earth
questions.correctAnswer: The joy that was set before him
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:2 explains that Jesus endured the cross because of the joy set before Him, highlighting the future glory and redemption of humanity. This is echoed in Philippians 2:8-11 where Jesus humbles Himself to death on a cross for exaltation. Psalm 16:11 speaks of joy in God’s presence, and Isaiah 53:11 portrays the Servant’s joy after suffering.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 12:4 say believers have not yet done in their struggle against sin?
questions.correctAnswer: Resisted unto blood
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:4 states believers have not yet resisted unto blood, implying they have not faced the ultimate persecution or martyrdom in their fight against sin. This is consistent with Acts 7:54-60 where Stephen is martyred, and Revelation 12:11 which speaks of overcoming by the blood of the Lamb. Romans 8:36 affirms that believers may be killed but not separated from Christ’s love.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Lord’s chastening as described in Hebrews 12:10?
options: That we might be partakers of his holiness
questions.correctAnswer: That we might be partakers of his holiness
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:10 teaches that God’s chastening is for our profit so that we might share in His holiness. This aligns with Proverbs 3:11-12 where the Lord disciplines those He loves, 1 Peter 1:16 calling believers to be holy as God is holy, and Revelation 3:19 where Jesus disciplines those He loves. Psalm 94:12 also speaks of blessedness in discipline.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12:11, what is the ultimate fruit yielded by chastening?
questions.correctAnswer: The peaceable fruit of righteousness
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:11 states chastening, though painful, yields the peaceable fruit of righteousness to those exercised by it. This corresponds with James 1:2-4 which teaches that trials produce perseverance leading to spiritual maturity, Galatians 5:22-23 about the fruit of the Spirit including peace and righteousness, and Romans 5:3-5 where suffering produces character and hope.

questions.question: In Hebrews 12:14, what two qualities are believers instructed to pursue?
options: Peace with all men and holiness
questions.correctAnswer: Peace with all men and holiness
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:14 commands believers to follow peace with all men and holiness, for without holiness no one will see the Lord. This is consistent with Romans 12:18 urging peace with all, 1 Peter 1:15-16 calling for holiness, and Isaiah 35:8 which speaks of the way of holiness. Matthew 5:9 affirms that peacemakers are called children of God.

questions.question: Who is warned about in Hebrews 12:16 for selling his birthright for a morsel of meat?
questions.correctAnswer: Esau
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:16 warns against being like Esau who sold his birthright for a single meal. This references Genesis 25:29-34 where Esau despised his inheritance. The passage teaches the danger of profaning sacred blessings for temporary gratification, similar to warnings in Proverbs 23:20-21 and 1 Timothy 6:9-10 about the love of worldly things.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 12:18 contrast the believers' experience with, in comparison to Mount Sinai?
options: Believers have not come to Mount Sinai, which was touched and burned with fire
Believers have come to Mount Sinai, experiencing fire and darkness
Believers have come to a desert without any mountains
Believers have come to Mount Zion which is fiery like Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: Believers have not come to Mount Sinai, which was touched and burned with fire
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:18 contrasts the terrifying, physical manifestations at Mount Sinai with the spiritual reality believers now approach. This recalls Exodus 19 where Sinai was covered with fire, smoke, and trembling. This contrast highlights the new covenant’s superiority (Jeremiah 31:31-34) and the spiritual Mount Zion (Hebrews 12:22).

questions.question: According to Hebrews 12:22, to what spiritual realities have the believers come?
options: Mount Sion, the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and an innumerable company of angels
Mount Sinai and the earthly Jerusalem
A place of fire and darkness
questions.correctAnswer: Mount Sion, the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and an innumerable company of angels
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:22 describes believers coming to Mount Zion, the heavenly Jerusalem, with countless angels, symbolizing the new covenant community. This imagery aligns with Revelation 21:2-3 describing the new Jerusalem, Psalm 48:2 about Mount Zion, and Isaiah 66:1 where God’s dwelling is in the heavens. It contrasts with the old covenant’s fearsome Sinai.

questions.question: Who is described as the mediator of the new covenant in Hebrews 12:24?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:24 identifies Jesus as the mediator of the new covenant, emphasizing His role in establishing a better covenant than the old one mediated by Moses (Hebrews 8:6-13). This matches Jeremiah 31:31-34’s prophecy of a new covenant and 2 Corinthians 3:6 where Christ ministers the new covenant. Jesus’ blood speaks better things than Abel’s (Genesis 4:10) illustrating the power of His atonement.

questions.question: What warning is given in Hebrews 12:25 regarding refusing Him who speaks from heaven?
options: We will not escape judgment if we turn away
We will be rewarded for independence
We may be forgiven without repentance
questions.correctAnswer: We will not escape judgment if we turn away
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:25 warns that refusing Him who speaks from heaven leads to judgment, just as those who refused the earthly voice did not escape. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 18:15-19 about heeding God’s prophet, Luke 10:16 where rejecting Jesus means rejecting God, and Revelation 2:7 calling for obedience to Christ’s voice.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 12:26 say God has promised to shake once more?
options: Not only the earth but also heaven
questions.correctAnswer: Not only the earth but also heaven
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:26 quotes a promise that God will shake not only the earth but also heaven, indicating a future cosmic upheaval. This corresponds with Haggai 2:6, Psalm 46:2-3 about God shaking the earth, and 2 Peter 3:10 describing the heavens passing away. The shaking signifies removal of transient things to establish God’s eternal kingdom.

questions.question: What is the significance of receiving a kingdom which cannot be moved as stated in Hebrews 12:28?
options: It calls for serving God with reverence and godly fear
It allows believers to ignore suffering
questions.correctAnswer: It calls for serving God with reverence and godly fear
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:28 teaches that receiving an unshakable kingdom demands serving God acceptably with reverence and godly fear. This aligns with 1 Chronicles 29:10-13 praising God’s kingdom, Romans 12:1 about presenting ourselves as living sacrifices, and Philippians 2:12 urging work out salvation with fear and trembling. It underscores holiness and worship in response to God’s eternal reign.

questions.question: How is God described in Hebrews 12:29, and what theological attribute does this emphasize?
options: A consuming fire, emphasizing His holiness and judgment
A gentle shepherd, emphasizing His mercy
A distant king, emphasizing His sovereignty
A silent watcher, emphasizing His patience
questions.correctAnswer: A consuming fire, emphasizing His holiness and judgment
questions.explanation: Hebrews 12:29 calls God a consuming fire, highlighting His holiness that purifies and His righteous judgment. This corresponds with Deuteronomy 4:24, Isaiah 33:14, and Revelation 1:14 describing God’s holiness and wrath. It emphasizes the reverence due to God and the necessity of holiness among His people.
